ratings.comment: Dr. Fernandez was an okay professor, but I had a hard time understanding the material the way she presented it. On top of that, the exam was extremely difficult compared to the level of depth that we covered during lecture. I can't tell if it was her teaching that made me test poorly or simply that the concepts were challenging. I'd say she is fine

DR. FERNANDEZ IS AN ABSOLUTELY HORRID PROFESSOR. SHE PROVIDED NO PREPARATION THAT WAS EVEN CLOSE IN DIFFICULTY TO HER EXAMS. SHE PRESENTED THE MATERIAL WITH SURFACE-LEVEL DETAIL. THE EXAM WAS EXTREMELY APPLICATION-BASED, UNLIKE HER LECTURES. I MEAN THIS WITH ALL MY HEART, DR. FERNANDEZ SHOULD NEVER EVER TEACH AN INTRO BIOLOGY CLASS AGAIN!!!

I honestly don't get negative reviews from Donna. If you read the book, listen to lecture multiple times to the point you actually understand, do hw/problem sets/lecture activities/quizzes, you will be fine. She explains things well and writes notes with you (which I believe is rare in biology). She is not a bad professor you want to avoid.

She was okay. One of three professors for Bio 151. She writes on paper with pen on a camera projector. Sometimes it can be difficult to read her handwriting. I wouldn't worry about having her for Bio 151 but I wouldn't take her in the future for a bio class. Only memorization. Made us memorize numbers which don't matter until upper level classes.

Dr. Fernandez's way of giving notes to students is so different, unique, and effective; unlike reading off slides, she writes and draws the notes with you. She is very fast paced and covers a lot of content is so little time, but if you stay on top of your notes and ask for help, you will be okay. Dr Fernandez also replies quickly to emails.

Her lectures were structured very simply in that she just wrote the notes down on a piece of paper for you to copy off of. Her unit was cells/ cellular metabolism which is a hard subject in general so I felt that she presented the material effectively rather than just reading off of a powerpoint (which would have made it harder).

Dr. Fernandez's lectures were a good pace, and it really helps that she draws out the diagrams and pictures. It helps to slow things down for note-taking. Exam was difficult and more detailed than the material taught.

She writes everything on paper and is very speedy to get through lots of concepts. I enjoyed this straight to the point lecture style for the cells section of the class although not everyone felt this way. Some of the material felt out of order but you can rewatch the lectures on canvas to relearn it or learn the concepts elsewhere.

Her lectures are easy to follow if you have a base knowledge of cell structure and function. Concepts are made clear in lecture, but factual knowledge has to come from the book. Exam required conceptual thinking but was not tricky or overly complex.

I had her for the first part of bio 151 for the cell and stuff. She wasnt an outstanding professor that explained concepts very well but she wasnt bad. Her lectures were recorded put on canvas which is super nice. Exam for her section definitely required conceptual thinking but want bad.
She was good at vocalizing material, but her notes for the class were handwritten and very sloppy so, if you didn't write down what she was saying, you didn't really get down much info
Dr. Fernandez wrote everything out as she was lecturing (doc cam) and that was really nice as we didn't have to figure out how to draw things! Good pace.

It seems like Dr. Fernandez cares about her students and answers questions clearly and promptly. However, her lectures and exams questions are not very clear. She tends to bounce around from idea to idea and she doesn't connect some important ideas very well. Reading the book was the most helpful in her section.

For the section in which she taught bio 151, I found it hard to follow her in class because she was so unorganized with presenting the material. She can rush through complicated ideas and concepts, and the way it was presented was convoluted. She also jumped around from topic to topic, making lectures hard to follow.

Donna is a HORRIBLE professor and needs to seriously reevaluate her teaching skills. She hardly explains anything, moves way too fast through difficult material, and jumps around often not linking concepts together. She is so unorganized and is not fit to teach this class at all. AVOID HER. She is 0/10 !!!!!

Exam was so hard, but her section is the worst, so once you get past that you'll be fine!! She talked in circles and sucked during office hours, and even if you feel like you know the material inside and out, you still probably won't get an A.

Lectures are a bit dull and it's easy to zone out, but if you do you will likely miss something. Exams were tough,(read questions carefully!!), and the class isn't curved. Reading the book and looking at diagrams certainly helps to understand things that are unclear in lecture, even though tests are only supposed to be from lecture material.

Donna's lecture were very hard to follow She jumps around a lot. She is very monotone. She says her tests are based off of lecture. Her tests were all trick questions. The average on the first exam was a 75% and the class is not curved.

Fernandez's lectures are confusing and hard to follow. The reading isn't necessary, but it helps a lot to clarify lectures. If you stay on top of the lectures and make sure you understand them, then you will do fine on the tests although they are somewhat tricky.

Incredibly disorganized while doing her lectures. Impossible to read your lecture notes. She says the tests are based only on lecture notes but is completely false. The tests are incredibly hard if you focus on only studying the lecture notes. I highly suggest you do the readings and take your own notes on the book if you want to do well.

Donna is really funny and knowledgable on anything plant physiology related. Be wary that is you don't show up, you're going to have a pretty hard time on the test. Lectures are recorded but she draws a lot of diagrams in the notes so the recordings are only helpful to listen to if you already went to class.

Gives a tough exam but as long as you put the time in will be fine.  Writes everything down for lectures, which is nice because it's clear what she is looking for.  I would suggest reading the book as well just to help with solidifying the concepts.  Very nice and willing to help if you reach out.

I had Donna for 151 Cell bio unit and 152 Botany unit. She is SO passionate about science and botany. She writes notes along with the lecture on the overhead, gives relative reading assignments, is SO CUTE and short. The first lecture about apical meristems, she threw cabbage and b sprouts at us. 3 with a passion, helpful after outside of lect!!

Her lectures are so bad and boring. She started the first class by saying that's she's old fashioned, and all of her lectures are going to be in writing. So all we get are a bunch of shorthand definitions and crude drawings, and nothing to review online because she doesn't have ppt slides. Her notes are very disorganized and hard to study.
Her notes suck, read the book carefully as she will test mainly from the book.
Her voice is monotonous and boring, her notes are awful, and her test is difficult. Avoid at all costs.

She said that we wouldn't need to use the book to do well on the test, and she was wrong. You need to do the readings otherwise you'll do average on the test (if you're looking to do well, do the readings). Also very unorganized.

Did the cell structure and function section of Bio 151. She said the tests would be written off the notes she took in lecture. Notes were extremely messy and disorganized. Test was hard. Did not find her very helpful at all.

I personally loved her lecture style.  She wrote almost everything down, so you knew what to copy. Pay attention to the things she says too though and paraphrase them in your own words. I didn't think the test was super hard or tricky (89100). She makes it very clear what she wants you to know for the test. I never bought the book, and I'm fine.
Extremely disorganized, speaks in monotone (very boring to listen to).  Tests were very conceptual and hard.  One of the worst professors I've had here so far, avoid if possible.
She is very concise and organized.  She simplifies the material which makes it easier to handle.
She's a ok professor. She's pretty clear most of the time and goes at a good rate, but not extremely interesting.
Donna is pretty good lecturer. She mostly uses the chalkboard, but shows a few slides of textbook figures. The book wasn't all that helpful besides looking at the pictures.

Dr. Fernandez was nice and had good intentions, but  was rather disorganized. Her notes were on the blackboard and were confusing and difficult to follow. I managed to pull off a B in this section, but I have to say I was much happier with the other two professors who used powerpoints. The test was tricky the and notecard didn't help much.

She does a lot of chalk talk, so it's a bad idea to miss lecture. She's really enthusiastic, but she's not a great drawer, so a lot of her diagrams are confusing. Most of what she writes on the board is disorganized. One strategy I recommend is actually not going to lecture and reading the book. Use her office hours with additional questions.
I thought she was great... At least better than the second prof. we have. May not have used powerpoints but still decently organized. If you attend lecture and get the notes you will be fine.
The worst professor i have ever had. Doesn't use power points, is all over the place in her lecture. You cant hear her. She is a horrible teacher even if she knows all the material.
Do not take this class. It's demanding, and totally boring. Unless you need to take it, I would NOT recommend it.

Doesn't use powerpoints so must attend lecture to get her chalkboard notes. Notes aren't very organized.  Read the book...it helps to follow along.  Test was somewhat tricky...still managed to get an A.  Go over the practice exam and ask TAs for answers on questions you have trouble with since she doesn't give you an answer key.
Test is tricky. I wish she would've used powerpoints, her chalkboard notes are hard to follow.

Very clear and organized, doesn't expect you to know anything she doesn't say in lecture. Her tests are a bit tricky but you just have to read the questions very carefully. Good at keeping me engaged enough to take notes.

I didn't like her lecturing style, she does jump around a bit, and talks quickly. Concepts can be tough to understand and book reading is all over the place as far as what corresponds to lecture. Exams are tricky, as many have mentioned, just on the edge of annoying.

I really enjoyed this class, and she was the better of the two professors, she tells you everything you need to know in class and the tests were fine. However, the book was more of a suggestion than a necessity.

She was a great teacher.  I really liked her. If you are a student who always goes to lecture and takes good notes, you will do well in her class. She takes notes on the chalkboard, which I like becasue she went at a slower pace.  If you study your notes you will do well. The book is a waste of money.

Arrogant and unreasonable.  Lectures are all done on chalk board-hard to keep it organized and actually learn.  Reading book helps, unless you can comprehend her garbage notes. Overall, I feel that she is ineffective at teaching her topic-plants are far too complex to rely on shoddy notes and diagrams.  Avoid if you can.
Very clear lectures, nice woman. Tests a bit trickier than necessary.

Donna is great! She moves at a good pace. Her tests were a little tricky but manageable if you know the material. She does use the chalk board but I found this helpful because she was forced to slow down because it too her awhile to write on the board. Very nice lady.
The tests were directly out of her notes pretty much.  This made lecture useful, and not so necessary to rely on the book.  Test was a little tricky.
Not the best lecturer.  Prefers to use the chalkboard instead of power points so it is hard to follow what she is doing--she writes so fast.  The test questions are more complex than they need to be.
Very easy class if you listen in lecture. The diagrams in the book are really helpful.
Doesn't care about students problems beacause they "dont affect her."

Boring lecture, terrible at writing notes on the board. Only good if you are a lecture oriented person. Flipped out because she was too lazy to write a new test so she used questions from an old one, and students used the old one to study. I wasnt aware using old tests to study was a bad thing.

I hate plants, so she wasn't able to hold my interest, but I thought she was a pretty solid lecturer.  I felt the test questions were unnecessarily complex, but not unfair.  I wasn't impressed, however, when she was furious when students had used an old test of hers to study from for the midterm (she didn't write a new one, that's her fault).

Her lectures are rather unorganized. She covers material from her, there, and everywhere. She keeps jumping from topic to topic. She constantly says "Allright...", "Okay.", or my favorite, "Okay....Allright". Her tests are much more difficult than they need to be! The format is messed up. There were only a few lectures that I actually stayed awake.
her teaching style is fine, and so is she
One of the best lecturers at UW.  Nicely organized.  Clear and direct explanations.  Exams actually require you to understand and think about the material not just regurgitate it.
Tests may include some extrapolation, but overall what she says in lecture is on the test.  Good teaching method, draws alot and is easy to follow in lecture.
Format of exams was awful; Questions were far from straight forward.
She's very clear and helpful about all the material. She also really loves plants and makes the lecture very, very interesting. Her exams are very straightforward - no tricks!
